ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned an intellectual history of 1600s England and how notions of property and labor developed in tandem with religious and political conflict involving the English crown.
Considering contextual and alternative readings of Hobbes, Locke, Defoe, Marvel, etc. putting them in historical context...which helps you get a lot more out of them

Through this course, I strengthened my ability to combine broader readings of texts with close readings in order to formulate better arguments and interpretations of the works we read. I learned how to integrate historical knowledge with the reading and writing skills I've developed in my other English courses, and the specific attention to ensuring that our interpretations of texts were grounded in historical or other fact was really helpful. Overall, the course expanded my reading skills by placing greater emphasis on a mix of close reading and high-level reading and improved my writing skills with Professor Mohamed's guidance.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The small size ended up being a strength as it motivated me to do the readings every week. Definitely a heavy volume of reading, so it is helpful to have friends in the class to fill in the gaps...good classic literature placed in historical context !

Would not mind a few more graded assignments earlier in the semester, but I guess this is pretty standard for Yale

Strengths: Great professor, interesting and historically important texts, engaging blend of close reading and higher-level reading

Weaknesses: No major weaknesses, potentially could make a few alterations to the student-led discussions to ensure they run more smoothly (posting questions 24 hours before, establishing clearer set-up for discussions, etc.) but I felt they worked well overall

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Succeeded: Professor Mohamed is a great lecturer and an engaging discussion leader. His slides were engaging and really....aesthetically pleasing even? 

could be improved: not much, I guess the course is pretty good overall in this regard. Having a few discussion questions distributed to the class beforehand so that we could guide how we read is an idea, this could help us stay engaged (a more difficult task than usual in Zoom university)
A five minute break in the middle of an hour and fifty minute class is CRUCIAL

I felt that pretty much everything was successful, with the one challenge potentially arising from the student-led discussions, which were at times difficult to engage with to the same extent that I think students otherwise would (see above for potential remedies in a virtual format).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend it, with the caveat that "land, liberty, and slavery" here focuses less on chattel/plantation slavery in the Americas and how property was developed in an exclusionary manner, and more so on English thought and politics that gave rise to colonialism and slavery in the New World. If you're looking for the former, you should probably go look at the AFAM/ER&M/AFST course listings one more time; if you're looking for the latter, you've 1000% come to the right place. Professor Mohamed is so engaging, guides discussion well, gives clear and thoughtful feedback, and on the whole truly cares about his students and their well-being. The readings were highly insightful if at some times difficult to understand, and I'm so glad to read Locke and Hobbes in this class' historical discussion of their thought.

Yes if you want to get a background in classic political thought like Hobbes and Locke. That was my main motivation and I definitely received that! 

Also great literature for the most part as well.

Yes, absolutely! Professor Mohamed is a wonderful teacher and really makes the class worthwhile. The material itself is quite interesting, even if the texts are a bit challenging to dissect at times, and I believe you can get a lot out of the course.
